question_details.query: What is the most cost-effective method for reducing human-primate conflict in agricultural areas?
How does the success rate of primate reintroduction programs vary between different continents?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies from The Gambia, Guinea, Liberia, the Republic of Congo, Gabon, Tanzania, Senegal, Uganda, and South Africa, many chimpanzee and gorilla reintroductions reported majority survival for at least 9 months to 5 years, with population increases documented in The Gambia and Tanzania, and several chimpanzee groups showing majority survival over 2–5 years (IDs: 1567, 1590, 1591, 1589). In Malaysia and Indonesia, outcomes included majority survival for orangutans (including 98% survival upon release and all Sumatran orangutans surviving at least three months), but one long-term study in Malaysia recorded a population decline after 33 years (IDs: 1589, 1591, 1567, 1590). In Thailand and Vietnam, multiple studies reported declines or very low survival, including a reintroduced population declining over three years and all reintroduced pygmy slow lorises assumed dead despite fostering (IDs: 1589, 1591, 1590, 1600). In Brazil and French Guiana, several studies found only a minority of reintroduced primates survived from 15 weeks up to several years, and most reintroduced golden lion tamarins did not survive over 1–7 years, whereas Belize recorded population increases and majority short-term survival in some cases (IDs: 1567, 1591, 1600, 1590). In Madagascar and India, persistence and survival were reported in several cases (including populations persisting 4–55 years in Madagascar and a population persisting at least four years in India), alongside other studies noting both majority and minority survival over months to years (IDs: 1567, 1590). Overall, the compiled evidence shows higher frequencies of majority survival and some population growth in several African country case studies; mixed results in Asian country case studies with both successes and notable failures; and mixed outcomes in American country case studies, with Belize showing increases but Brazil and French Guiana often reporting minority survival (IDs: 1567, 1590, 1591, 1589, 1600, 1595).
summary_statements: In studies from The Gambia, Guinea, Liberia, the Republic of Congo, Gabon, Tanzania, Senegal, Uganda, and South Africa, many chimpanzee and gorilla reintroductions reported majority survival for at least 9 months to 5 years.
Population increases of reintroduced primates were documented in The Gambia and Tanzania.
Several reintroduced chimpanzee groups showed majority survival over 2–5 years.
In Malaysia and Indonesia, outcomes for orangutan reintroduction included majority survival.
Orangutan reintroduction outcomes in Malaysia and Indonesia included 98% survival upon release and all Sumatran orangutans surviving at least three months.
One long-term study in Malaysia recorded a decline in the reintroduced orangutan population after 33 years.
In Thailand and Vietnam, multiple studies on primate reintroduction reported population declines or very low survival.
A reintroduced primate population in Thailand or Vietnam declined over three years.
All reintroduced pygmy slow lorises in one study were assumed dead despite fostering.
In Brazil and French Guiana, several studies found only a minority of reintroduced primates survived from 15 weeks up to several years.
Most reintroduced golden lion tamarins in Brazil and French Guiana did not survive over 1–7 years.
In some primate reintroduction cases, Belize recorded population increases and majority short-term survival.
In Madagascar and India, persistence and survival of reintroduced primates were reported in several cases.
Reintroduced primate populations in Madagascar have persisted for 4–55 years.
A reintroduced primate population in India persisted for at least four years.
Studies in Madagascar and India noted both majority and minority survival of reintroduced primates over months to years.
Compiled evidence shows higher frequencies of majority survival and some population growth for reintroduced primates in several African country case studies.
Case studies of primate reintroduction in Asian countries show mixed results, with both successes and notable failures.
Case studies of primate reintroduction in American countries show mixed outcomes.
Among American country case studies, Belize showed population increases for reintroduced primates, while Brazil and French Guiana often reported minority survival.

question_details.query: What is the impact of plastic pollution in waterways on primate populations that live near rivers?
